section_title: Getting Sensors Connected to Graphical Analysis
content: Vernier Go Direct sensors can connect via Bluetooth wireless technology or USB. Wired LabQuest sensors connect via USB interfaces.

subsections.content: Go Direct sensors connect one-to-one via Bluetooth to computers, Chromebooks, smartphones, or tablets.

procedures.instruction: Make sure your sensor is powered on
From the Sensors box, locate your sensor in the Discovered Wireless Devices list using its serial number
Click or tap Connect to connect to your sensor

subsections.content: Automatically connect to the sensor with the strongest signal, typically the closest sensor.

procedures.instruction: Ensure your sensor is powered on and near your device
procedures.tip: Signal strength may vary; proximity doesn't always guarantee strongest signal

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Proximity Connect to initiate automatic connection
Repeat the process to connect additional sensors one at a time
procedures.tip: Connect one sensor at a time using this method

subsections.content: USB sensors and Go Direct sensors can connect directly to computers and Chromebooks via USB cable.

procedures.instruction: Launch Graphical Analysis and select Sensor Data Collection
Connect the sensor to your computer or Chromebook via USB
procedures.tip: If using wired sensors, connect through an interface like Go!Link, LabQuest Mini, or LabQuest Stream

procedures.instruction: Configure sensor channels if your sensor has multiple channels

subsections.content: Some Go Direct sensors have multiple sensor channels with default configurations.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Sensor Channels to modify the configuration
Select the desired sensor channels for your experiment
procedures.tip: Some channels cannot be used simultaneously

procedures.instruction: Click Done to continue with your experiment

content: Sensor meters show current readings and provide access to calibration, zeroing, reversing, and unit selection.

subsections.content: Most sensors use factory calibration, but some require custom calibration.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap a sensor meter to access configuration tools
Choose Calibrate to initiate sensor calibration
procedures.tip: Detailed calibration instructions are in sensor user manuals at www.vernier.com/manuals

subsections.content: Set the current sensor reading to zero, creating an offset for future readings.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap the sensor meter
Choose Zero to set current reading to zero
procedures.tip: Zeroing does not affect already collected data

subsections.content: Swap the sign of sensor readings for sensors that read positive and negative values.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap the sensor meter
Turn on Reverse to swap the sign of readings
procedures.tip: Previously collected data are not changed

subsections.content: Some sensors can display data in different units of measure.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap the sensor meter
Choose the desired unit from the Units dropdown menu
procedures.tip: Choosing a new unit changes all existing and subsequent data

content: Configure data collection parameters including mode, rate, duration, and triggering options.

subsections.content: Time-based data collection records sensor readings at regular time intervals.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Mode to open Data Collection Settings
Select Time Based mode (default for most sensors)
Set Time Units (seconds, milliseconds, minutes, or hours)
Adjust Rate (samples per time unit) or Interval (time between samples)
procedures.tip: Rate and Interval are reciprocals; changing one automatically changes the other

procedures.instruction: Set collection duration or choose to end manually

subsections.content: Choose to start collection manually or on a triggering event.

procedures.instruction: For manual start, select Manually option (default)
procedures.tip: Click Collect button to start

procedures.instruction: For triggered start, select On a Triggering Event
Choose the sensor and set the trigger threshold value
Select whether trigger activates on increasing or decreasing past threshold
Optionally collect data points before the trigger (negative time values)

subsections.content: Event-based collection uses an attribute other than time as the independent variable.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Mode and select Event Based
Choose between Events with Entry (prompts for value) or Selected Events (auto-numbered)
Optionally enable Average over 10 seconds for averaged readings
Rename the Event column and provide units as needed

subsections.content: Drop Counting mode records data points each time a drop is detected by the Drop Counter.

procedures.instruction: Connect a Drop Counter sensor
procedures.tip: Drop Counting is the default mode when a Drop Counter is connected

procedures.instruction: Ensure at least one other sensor is connected for data collection
procedures.tip: Drop Counting requires a Drop Counter plus at least one other sensor

subsections.content: Photogate Timing mode records time-based measurements as objects pass through photogates.

procedures.instruction: Connect a photogate sensor (wired BTD Photogate, Go Direct Photogate, or Projectile Launcher)
procedures.tip: Photogate Timing is the default mode when these sensors are connected

procedures.instruction: Select measurement type: Speed Through Gate, Linear Motion, Angular Motion, Timer/Period, or Projectile Launcher
Configure parameters based on measurement type (object width, gate separation, spacing, etc.)

section_title: Setting Up the Display (Graph, Data Table, and Meters)
content: Graphical Analysis automatically displays views based on experiment type and connected sensors. Customize using View Options.

subsections.content: Display only graphs, data table, or meters for a focused view.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap View Options
Select 1 Graph, 2 Graphs, 3 Graphs, Table, or Meter
procedures.tip: 1 Graph is default for time-based data with single sensor

subsections.content: Show two elements side-by-side with adjustable split.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap View Options
Select combinations like Graph and Data Table, or Graph and Meter
procedures.tip: Drag the resize handle to adjust the split between elements

subsections.content: Display graph, data table, and meters simultaneously.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap View Options
Select Graph, Data Table, and Meter
procedures.tip: Graph displays on left; table and meters split vertically on right

content: Start and stop data collection, and collect multiple data sets for comparison.

subsections.content: Collect sensor data at regular time intervals.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Collect to start data collection
procedures.tip: Use space bar on keyboard to start/stop while GA has focus

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Stop to end collection, or wait for automatic end
Click or tap Zoom to scale graph to fit all data

subsections.content: Collect additional data sets for comparison.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Collect again after completing first data set
procedures.tip: Original data set is saved automatically

procedures.instruction: To plot original data, click y-axis label and turn on columns from desired data set

subsections.content: Collect data points based on events rather than time.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Collect to enable Keep Point button
Click or tap Keep Point when ready to record a data point
Enter the Event value if using Events with Entry mode
procedures.tip: Sensor reading at Keep Point time is recorded

procedures.instruction: Continue until all data points collected, then click Stop

content: Use the free-hand sketching tool to add predictions before collecting data.

subsections.content: Draw a prediction on the graph to compare with actual data.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Graph Tools and choose Add Prediction
procedures.tip: Graph expands to full screen while prediction tool is active

procedures.instruction: Click-and-drag or touch-and-drag to sketch your prediction
Name the prediction if desired
Click Apply to add prediction to graph
procedures.tip: Drag again to redraw if you don't like first attempt

procedures.instruction: Collect data to compare with prediction

subsections.content: Hide or delete predictions as needed.

procedures.instruction: To hide, click y-axis label and turn off the prediction
To delete, click y-axis label, then Other Options next to prediction, and choose Delete Prediction

content: Create position or velocity targets to match with your motion.

subsections.content: Match your motion to a position vs. time target graph.

procedures.instruction: Connect a Motion Detector, Motion Encoder, or Sensor Cart
procedures.tip: Add Graph Match is only available with motion sensors

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Graph Tools and choose Add Graph Match
Choose Position target
procedures.tip: Position match is good for students new to graph matching

procedures.instruction: Start data collection and move to match the displayed graph
procedures.tip: Repeat collection as often as desired

subsections.content: Match your motion to a velocity vs. time target graph.

procedures.instruction: Click or tap Graph Tools and choose Add Graph Match
Choose Velocity target
Start data collection and move to match constant velocity segments

subsections.content: Hide or delete graph match targets.

procedures.instruction: To hide, click y-axis label and turn off the Graph Match target
To delete, click y-axis label, then Other Options next to target, and choose Delete Graph Match

content: See Chapter 6 for detailed information on analyzing collected sensor data.

subsections.content: Sensor data can be analyzed using tools in Chapter 6.

procedures.instruction: Refer to Chapter 6 for complete data analysis options
procedures.tip: Analysis tools include examine, statistics, curve fits, tangent, and integral
